I'll echo  Kevin 's sentiments below. I had the honor and privilege to sign off on an earned Railroading merit badge today, give group guided tours to over 70 people, and share the message of railroad preservation with an interested and eager general public.  Any way you measure the success of an event, whether it be by attendance, earnings, or exposure, I think the URHS knocked this one out of the park. description: Kevin Phalon  added  2 new photos . I'll use this photo to sum up today: Every one of these stubs represents a person who we brought into today's "Railroad Museum [for a day]", an event that I have had the privilege to be the Chairman of over the last 11 weeks... Over 1500 people came in and out of our location that is open to the public one day per year. To put that in perspective, this was at capacity for our train yard. Not a single exhibit didn't have a line of at least a dozen people throughout the 7 hour day. Street parking was nowhere to be found, and every shuttle bus showed up full. We had it all: locals, people who came from states away, families, kids, seniors, college students, photographers, hipsters, railroaders.   A day like today proves that historic preservation is not only alive, but can be appreciated by anyone, as long as you can present it in an accessible, enjoyable, and educational way. That was our goal when  Rudy Garbely  and I set off on this insane and incredible project in July, and I have no reservations in calling it a 100% success.  Thank you so much to everyone who came out to support us today. I have never seen so many people from so many different aspects of my life in one place. I'm proud to have the work I appreciated by people I care about!
